messageBody:
On 21/08/07, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
> Colin,
>
> Is it easy for a human scanning the class names to figure out which
> are test classes?
>
> In case you'd like to submit a feature request, you'll need to do it
> on the ant side: it's ant's junit task, not junit's ant task. :-)
>
> David
>
>
> On 8/20/07, Colin Goudie <colin.goudie@...> wrote:
> > Jan,
> >
> > That is exactly what we do however, not all classes in the test package are
> > tests. There are Mocks, utility classes etc.. As well as Test classes that
> > are annotated with Test-NG. However, junit's ant task isn't smart enough to
> > distinguish the difference. I find that pretty horrible! What is the use of
> > a @Test annotation if it isn't used?? pretty crazy. Thanks for the help
> > though.

I think it's probably worth asking this question on the ant-users
list. From when I used to read that list, I know that the ANT
developers were very careful to ensure that older versions of Java (I
think they strive for 1.2 compatibility) were the target environment.
This may have changed, or maybe you could put in a feature request to
gracefully fallback when attempting to read annotations using Java 5
features, or ASM if it's available, etc. Since the ANT JUnit task
works with JUnit4, that must assume a Java 5, so it's worth asking.

Cheers,

James
